Groups are constructed based on the feeling of identifying with a unit that transcends the individual, where their relationship with others is interdependent, and which defines their identity and sense of belonging. All groups have roles and functions, which, depending on the setting and the type of group, can be defined with varying degrees of formality and explicitness. The way in which the allocation and dynamics of roles can be functional to a group and strengthen it, or make it become dysfunctional, disrupting the rapport of the group or causing it to break up, is of interest to psychology

fields.name_eng: Learning
fields.description_eng: Learning is the process of acquiring new behaviours and skills that enable the subject to process information from their environment, while remaining in balance with it. It can also be understood as all of the changes in behaviour that occur as a result of interaction with the environment. How different learning processes are conveyed depends on the subject’s biological makeup, the conditions in which this takes place and on environmental stimuli. The family and educational institutions are consequently fundamental in learning behaviour patterns. Disorders or conditions affecting the acquisition and development of cognitive skills are usually referred to as learning difficulties

fields.name_eng: Mental health
fields.description_eng: Mental health can be defined as the equilibrium between the individual and their environment, so that environmental stimuli tend to be pleasant, tolerable or functional to the subject’s adaptive capacities. The concept of health does not reflect a definitive and established state, but a dynamic and fluctuating process, so that it is difficult for a subject to be regarded as entirely mental healthy or entirely mentally ill. Consequently, health and mental illness are not two exhaustive categories into which people can be divided, but should be seen as the opposite ends of a continuum that covers various modes and gradations. What is considered healthy behaviour varies widely, depending on the era and social context, and the concept of health can be seen as a socio-historical construction

fields.name_eng: Mind
fields.description_eng: The mind can be defined as a human faculty essentially enabling intellectual processes such as perception, memory, imagination and the production of thought in general. It also enables processes that are not strictly intellectual, linked to emotions and feelings. Throughout history, the mind has been seen as an immaterial substratum of psychological activity, in contrast to the materiality of the body. This has led to philosophical debate about the relationship between body and mind. While this debate goes beyond the scope of psychology as a subject, it appears in most psychological theories concerning the mind. There are theses that argue that the mind is irreducible and separate, while others attempt to explain the mind entirely on the basis of the body, and others exclude the concept of the mind from the scope of psychological study

fields.name_eng: Symptoms
fields.description_eng: Symptoms are the manifestation of an abnormal or pathological emotional state in a subject. Symptoms contrast with signs, in that a sign is an objective verifiable fact independent of the subject’s statements and they are related to syndrome, understood as a set of symptoms that define a mental disorder or pathology. Symptoms indicate the levels of distress and discomfort experienced by the subject, as well as their degree of emotional integration. According to current thought and the theoretical approach, symptoms can be regarded as an expression of unconscious conflicts, as a manifestation of limitations or difficulties in successfully adapting to one’s environment, or as a result of the prevalence of misconceptions and false expectations in one’s perception of reality. Identifying and distinguishing symptoms in a subject is crucial to diagnosing clinical conditions and making decisions about treatment

fields.name_eng: Unconsciousness
fields.description_eng: Unconsciousness is part of the mental apparatus made up of repressed desires, impulses or representations that are intolerable and inaccessible to consciousness. As a component, it is distinguished in a conventional sense from consciousness and from pre-consciousness, part of the mental apparatus that houses content that is unconscious but could become conscious. The functioning of the unconscious requires the free flow of mental energy, and may therefore be associated with different repressed representations. It also requires negation of the principle of non-contradiction, insofar as opposing representations and desires co-exist with each other, and of temporality, insofar as there is no distinction between past, present and future in the unconscious. The term can also be used in a dynamic sense, referring to mental content that remains beyond consciousness, whether this is pre-conscious or unconscious content in a narrow sense

fields.name_eng: Authority
fields.description_eng: Authority is having the right to use power to give orders, make decisions, and enforce obedience. It can also include the right to act or not act in a specified way, and it can be delegated from one person or organization to another. There are several ways of classifying the exercise of authority, and these in turn impact on the form of government

fields.name_eng: Citizenship
fields.description_eng: Citizenship is the act of being a member of a given geographic level with the rights and duties that are defined by the governance of those geographies. A citizen of a state may have different rights and duties depending on where citizenship resides, and at what level these rights and duties are being recognized or analysed. Recently, the notion of “global citizenship” has been employed and questioned by several theorists

fields.name_eng: Conflict
fields.description_eng: Conflict is the dynamic process of actual or perceived opposition between individuals, groups or countries. This could be opposition over positions, interests or values. Most theorists would distinguish between non-violent and violent conflict. In this distinction, non-violent conflict can be a useful mechanism for social change and transformation, while violent conflict is harmful and asks for conflict resolution. Some theorists of political science state that violent conflict is sometimes unavoidable

fields.name_eng: Cooperation
fields.description_eng: The term cooperation is used to refer to people working together, usually for mutual benefit. In global politics cooperation can be witnessed in, for example, a joint operation or action to provide humanitarian aid. Exploring the extent to which international cooperation occurs in global politics is a key aspect of the study of relationships between countries. At the local political level, cooperation is also a paramount feature of any political organization where people must take collective action towards desired goals or results

fields.name_eng: Globalization
fields.description_eng: Globalization is a process by which local, regional and national economies, societies and cultures are becoming increasingly integrated and connected. The term refers primarily to economic activity and to the reduction of barriers and borders in order to encourage international trade and global distribution of goods and services. Globalization is a process which has been taking place for centuries but the pace has quickened in recent years. Globalization has also affected the process of political change as new governing (global or international) institutions take the stage. The concept of globalization has been questioned by some who have stated that it hides more than it reveals (“westernization” or “neo-imperialism”)

fields.name_eng: Government
fields.description_eng: A group of people that rule/administer a nation, community or unit. It sets and administers public policy and exercises executive, political and sovereign power through customs, institutions, and laws within a state or units in question. A government can be classified into many types—democracy, republic, monarchy, aristocracy, and dictatorship are just a few. It can also refer to the practice of governing

fields.name_eng: Ideologies
fields.description_eng: Ideology refers, in a general sense, to a system of political ideas; in which law and politics seem inextricably intertwined. It is generally seen as conceptual and a system of ideas and ideals, especially one that forms the basis of economic or political policy. It can also refer to the ideas and manner of thinking of a group, social class, or individual

fields.name_eng: Integration
fields.description_eng: Integration is the process by which groups of people or individuals that have previously been segregated are intermixed (unified). Integration can also be classified by type. As such it is important to be aware of the different facets of this concept, for example, economic integration: such as the European Union and Mercosur; or political integration: a process through which territories formerly separated are unified

fields.name_eng: Interdependence
fields.description_eng: Interdependence is when groups of people, objects or things are dependent on each other. It is based on mutuality: a reciprocal relation between interdependent entities (objects or individuals or groups). However, the relationship may not be of equality. Interdependence can be voluntary or involuntary, when it might lead to conflict between the parts. In the latter case, struggles for independence may emerge

fields.name_eng: Leadership
fields.description_eng: A process whereby an individual influences a group of individuals for a certain goal. It is a complex phenomenon that touches on many other important organizational, social and personal processes. Political leadership is above all a quality, and the reasons that explain leadership of a person or group are contingent on that society

fields.name_eng: Power
fields.description_eng: Power can be seen as ability to effect change in the world and, rather than being viewed as a unitary or independent force, as an aspect of relations among people. Contested relationships between and among peoples dominate politics, particularly in this era of increased globalization, and so understanding the dynamics of power plays a prominent and important role in understanding global politics. At the level of local or national politics, power can be viewed as the ability or official authority to decide what is best for others. It is the ability to decide who will have access to resources and includes the capacity to exercise control and authority over others

fields.name_eng: Rights
fields.description_eng: Human rights are basic rights and entitlements which many argue one should be able to claim simply by virtue of being a human being. Many contemporary thinkers argue that they are essential for living a life of dignity, are inalienable, and are universal. The Universal Declaration of Human Rights adopted by the United Nations in 1948 is recognized as the beginning of the formal discussion of human rights around the world. Civil and political rights form the original and main part of international human rights. Natural rights are rights not contingent upon the laws, customs, or beliefs of any particular culture or government, and therefore universal and inalienable. Legal rights are those bestowed onto a person by the law of a particular political and legal system, and therefore relative to specific cultures and governments. Legal rights are almost always qualified, whether by implication, by the law which created the right itself or by legal rights held by others. A legal right can be enforced in court

fields.name_eng: Agency
fields.description_eng: Agency is the capacity of human beings to act in meaningful ways that affect their own lives and those of others. Agency may be constrained by class, gender, religion and other social and cultural factors. This term implies that individuals have the capacity to create, change and influence events. Anthropological and sociological research that emphasizes agency focuses on humans acting to promote their interests and the interests of the groups to which they belong (although what constitutes “interest” may be subject to debate)

fields.name_eng: Community
fields.description_eng: Traditionally, it referred to a geographically bounded group of people in face-to-face contact, with a shared system of beliefs and norms operating as a socially functioning whole. Communities existed within a common social structure and government. More recently, communities have also been defined as interest groups accessed through space, as in “internet communities” or “communities of taste”. With the advent of globalism and global studies that often question the stability of territories, space and place, community is now a highly contested concept

fields.name_eng: Culture
fields.description_eng: Culture refers to organized systems of symbols, ideas, explanations, beliefs and material production that humans create and manipulate in the course of their daily lives. Culture includes the customs by which humans organize their physical world and maintain their social structure. While many anthropologists have thought of culture simply as shared systems of experiences and meanings, more recent formulations of the concept recognize that culture may be the subject of disagreement and conflict within and among societies. Cultures can be studied at different levels, from the group (for example, tribes), to a locality to a nation. For anthropologists and sociologists, cultural relativism is a methodological principle that emphasizes the importance of searching for meaning within the local context

fields.name_eng: Identity
fields.description_eng: Group of characteristics, traits, and class of attributes that define who we are. Self-identity refers to one´s concept of oneself while social-identity refers to one´s sense of self as a member of a social group or groups. Identity is always relational (created in “mirrorlike” fashion) as it depends on the images that others project back on us. An individual´s identity emerges at the intersection of several group belongingness

fields.name_eng: Institutions
fields.description_eng: Organizations or establishments that possess a normative system, social purpose and certain endurance over time. Institutions transcend individual human lives. Giddens (1984: 24) states that “institutions by definition are the more enduring features of social life.” Social institutions include: religions, family-marriage, economic institutions, education, and the government (politics).

fields.name_eng: Meaning
fields.description_eng: Meaning is both constructed and transmitted through cultural categories. These attribute particular significance to persons, relations, objects, places and events. This enables people to make sense of, and give order to, their experiences, which may in turn reinforce or change meaning

fields.name_eng: Norms
fields.description_eng: Combinations of agreed-upon rules and expectations that guide behaviour. Norms vary widely across cultural groups. Sociologists and anthropologists usually classify norms into different types, such as folkways (costumes), mores (moral), taboos (forbidden behaviours), and laws (formal legal codes of conduct). Norms change depending on the person´s or group´s social position (for example, gender norms encompass what is expected of males and females in a given society). Roles and norms are analysed by anthropology and sociology to account for what people do

fields.name_eng: Social interactions
fields.description_eng: Process by which people act and react in relation to others. Societies have always interacted with one another and they define themselves, in significant ways, through these interactions. Societies interact with and transform the environment. The study of the interaction of individual and groups is at the heart of both sociology and anthropology. In sociology, the symbolic interaction perspective, explains society through the interaction between individuals and the meaning they give to their actions

fields.name_eng: Socialization
fields.description_eng: Socialization is a complex process by which individuals incorporate and learn from their surrounding and progressively adapt to social norms and roles. Theorists usually make a distinction between three socialization processes: primary, secondary and tertiary. Social reproduction is the concept that, over time, groups of people reproduce their social structure and patterns of behaviour. This includes not only the enculturation of individual human beings but also the reproduction of cultural institutions, and material means of production and consumption. Social reproduction may be contested, leading to social change

fields.name_eng: Social position (roles/status)
fields.description_eng: It is the social place which individuals occupy in society. Social positions affect individuals and groups and it is defined by ascribed roles (behaviours and activities expected from an individual or group) and status (value, rights and responsibly which are granted to certain social positions). To each social status corresponds specific social roles. Social positions are context dependent

fields.name_eng: Structure
fields.description_eng: Structures are a group of social arrangements in societies that are seen as external to the individuals. Structure-centred perspectives view social action as determined by social and material context, such as physical environment, access to resources, community organization, social institutions, and the state

fields.name_eng: Subjectivity
fields.description_eng: Group of perceptions and ideas that are determined by the point of view of the subject. The concept is usually placed in antagonism to “objectivity” which implies an intersubjective, verifiable, non-bias reading of reality. Subjectivity is always determined by a subject’s belonging (be it historical, social, class, cultural, political, and so on). At the same time, this concept is intimately related to the methods of sociological and anthropological inquiry. Qualitative methodology recognizes that the subjectivity of the researcher is intimately involved in scientific research. The analysis of anthropological and sociological data consists of discovering consistencies and other recurrent patterns in the data. This discovery process often relies heavily on the theoretical framework and point of view of the researcher

fields.name_eng: Authority
fields.description_eng: Someone or something with a degree of power to influence the ideas that other people may have, the beliefs that they hold or the behaviour that they may exhibit. People, objects and deities may have varying degrees of authority within a particular religion

fields.name_eng: Beliefs
fields.description_eng: Ideas that are accepted as being true, or being the case, sometimes in the absence of empirical evidence. In order to become a belief, faith or trust is required in a particular idea. Beliefs inform the practices, rituals/rites and doctrines of religious believers. The relationship between belief and knowledge is debatable: Plato argued that a justified true belief constituted knowledge, but Radford (1966) argues that it is possible to have knowledge without belief

fields.name_eng: Deity
fields.description_eng: A supreme being, or God, that is worshipped or revered by people. A deity will often be the foundation stone of religion, from which religious texts, moral codes, rites/rituals and beliefs will all refer to or gain authority. As creators of the universe, deities provide explanations for the existence of humans and provide meaning to life. Deities are, however, not necessary for religion: Buddhism, Jainism and Taoism respectively all lack deities

fields.name_eng: Destiny
fields.description_eng: The notion that there is some kind of fate or determined course of events that governs people’s lives. Destiny may entail the idea that humans are not free to choose the direction that their lives take but are instead subject to either the will of a deity, or that they are determined by physical laws associated with cause and effect. Alternatively, some religious believers hold that while our destiny may be set and decided by a deity, we are free to choose the means by which we achieve it

fields.name_eng: Doctrines
fields.description_eng: A set of authoritative principles or values which teach people what to believe and how to live in order to achieve the objective of any particular religion. There are often principles which relate to religious customs or practices, but doctrines may also be in the form of ethical norms

fields.name_eng: Morality
fields.description_eng: A system of establishing right and wrong. Often informed by religious beliefs, morality may define how a good life can be lived and defines the behaviour that is deemed acceptable and unacceptable by a particular community. Whilst there are many morals that are common to different religions, there are often different morals within each religion. This could be because of religious believers taking morals from different sources, or interpretations of those sources from different religious leaders

fields.name_eng: Religious feelings
fields.description_eng: Sensations experienced as a result of engaging in practices which occur as a result of a religious belief. These feelings will usually be positive, and may reinforce or strengthen faith in the original religious belief. Religious feelings should be recognized as being distinct from a religious experience: in addition to including religious feelings, religious experiences may entail a "feeling of absolute dependence" (Schleiermacher quoted in Behrens, G. December 1998. “Feeling of Absolute Dependence or Absolute Feeling of Dependence? (What Schleiermacher Really Said and Why It Matters)”. Religious Studies. Vol 34, number 4. Pp 471–481.) or knowledge of an absolute reality

fields.name_eng: Rituals and rites
fields.description_eng: Acts of worship pertaining to a certain religion. Religious festivals may also be regarded as rituals and/or rites. They tend to be regarded as sacred or holy, and specific practices may vary between different groups within the same religion. Rituals may serve to re-enforce beliefs as well as manifest them. They may also allow religious believers to associate themselves with a deity or ideology and reinforce feelings of belonging to a particular community in a particular time, place and space

fields.name_eng: Sacredness
fields.description_eng: Set apart and revered with great importance. Sacred objects, or customs may be regarded as holy and will often be considered to be worthy of a great deal of respect

fields.name_eng: Symbolism
fields.description_eng: Objects, people or actions that have a greater, more significant meaning that they initially seem to have upon first consideration. Symbols represent something other than what they are in themselves. Religious symbols tend to have a deeper meaning that is only fully understood through grasping key religious ideas, doctrines and practices of a particular religion

fields.name_eng: Tradition
fields.description_eng: Beliefs, doctrines or practices that are passed down through generations so that they become an established part of the religion. Religious traditions may be communicated through religious texts, religious leaders, and religious believers. Perhaps because of the sentiments associated with traditions, they may be difficult to change or adapt

fields.name_eng: Worship
fields.description_eng: To revere a deity or to express one’s devotion to their religion through their behaviour. This behaviour may take the form of prayer, rites/rituals, meditation or obedience to the moral code proposed by the religion. Worship may be considered to be a religious experience, if a religious experience is defined as an experience in a religious context

fields.name_eng: Balance: biology specific
fields.description_eng: The dynamic equilibrium that exists among members of a stable natural community; the regulation of the internal environment of an organism

fields.name_eng: Balance: chemistry specific
fields.description_eng: A state of equilibrium or stable distribution

fields.name_eng: Conditions: chemistry specific
fields.description_eng: The environment, both physical and chemical, of a reaction or process; factors which contribute to an interaction including temperature, pressure, concentration, pH and the absence or presence of a catalyst

fields.name_eng: Consequences
fields.description_eng: The observable or quantifiable effects, results, or outcomes correlated with an earlier event or events

fields.name_eng: Development: physics specific
fields.description_eng: The process of applying theory to data and observations in order to improve, progress, or further scientific understanding

fields.name_eng: Energy
fields.description_eng: The capacity of an object to do work or transfer heat

fields.name_eng: Environment: biology specific
fields.description_eng: All of the biotic and abiotic factors that act on an organism, population or community and influence its survival, evolution and development

fields.name_eng: Environment: physics specific
fields.description_eng: A description of the universe or a closed system through the application of the laws of physics; the complex of physical conditions or climate affecting a habitat or community

fields.name_eng: Evidence
fields.description_eng: Support for a proposition derived from observation and interpretation of data

fields.name_eng: Form
fields.description_eng: The features of an object that can be observed, identified, described, classified and categorized

fields.name_eng: Function
fields.description_eng: A purpose, a role or a way of behaving that can be investigated; a mathematical relationship between variables

fields.name_eng: Interaction
fields.description_eng: The effect or effects two or more systems, bodies, substances or organisms have on one another, so that the overall result is not simply the sum of the separate effects

fields.name_eng: Models
fields.description_eng: Representations used for testing scientific theories or proposals that can be accurately repeated and validated; simulations used for explaining or predicting processes which may not be observable or to understand the dynamics of multiple underlying phenomena of a complex system

fields.name_eng: Movement
fields.description_eng: The act, process, or result of displacing from one location or position to another within a defined frame of reference

fields.name_eng: Patterns
fields.description_eng: The distribution of variables in time or space; sequences of events or features

fields.name_eng: Transfer: chemistry specific
fields.description_eng: The net movement of matter or particles from one location to another

fields.name_eng: Transformation: biology specific
fields.description_eng: Differentiation of a cell; change of energy form, including at a molecular level; alteration of molecules and metabolism and/or genetic make-up of an organism or species and consequently a community, relative to external factors

fields.name_eng: Transformation: physics specific
fields.description_eng: A change from one well-defined state to another well-defined state; an alteration in form or condition, including energy and particle nature.

fields.name_eng: Change
fields.description_eng: A variation in size, amount or behaviour

fields.name_eng: Equivalence
fields.description_eng: The state of being identically equal or interchangeable, applied to statements, quantities or expressions

fields.name_eng: Generalization
fields.description_eng: A general statement made on the basis of specific examples

fields.name_eng: Justification
fields.description_eng: Valid reasons or evidence used to support a statement

fields.name_eng: Measurement
fields.description_eng: A method of determining quantity, capacity or dimension using a defined unit

fields.name_eng: Models
fields.description_eng: Depictions of real-life events using expressions, equations or graphs

fields.name_eng: Patterns
fields.description_eng: Sets of numbers or objects that follow a specific order or rule

fields.name_eng: Quantity
fields.description_eng: An amount or number

fields.name_eng: Representation
fields.description_eng: The manner in which something is presented

fields.name_eng: Simplification
fields.description_eng: The process of reducing to a less complicated form

fields.name_eng: Space
fields.description_eng: The frame of geometrical dimensions describing an entity

fields.name_eng: Systems
fields.description_eng: Groups of interrelated elements

fields.name_eng: Audience
fields.description_eng: An individual or group who receive and/or respond to arts. Addressing this concept includes examining strategies for engaging audience, different types of audiences and how the audience–artist relationship affects and influences the arts

fields.name_eng: Boundaries
fields.description_eng: The parameters that define a personality, a culture, an environment, civil law, a skill set or a belief structure. The concept of boundaries can include: themes, issues and concepts; the imagined or physical boundary between performance space and audience; the subversive or provocative nature of the arts; the dividing line between what is real and what is fictional; private and public space; the relationships between characters

fields.name_eng: Composition
fields.description_eng: The intentional organization or contrast, balance, arrangement or awareness of the elements and principles of art for a particular purpose in the creation of art. These may include tension and release, repetition and variety, unison and harmony, sound and silence, theme and variation, and dynamics and energy.

fields.name_eng: Expression
fields.description_eng: The representation of feelings and emotions, ideas, thoughts, beliefs, values and opinions in the process of visual or physical articulation. It can include signs, symbols, semiotics or any other imagery to capture the artist intention. It is something you do, create or play that shows what you think or feel. Expression facilitates the communication of an idea.

fields.name_eng: Genre
fields.description_eng: Different artistic expressions that create a style when grouped by the same use of techniques, in a distinctive manner regarding theme, content or practice.

fields.name_eng: Innovation
fields.description_eng: An altered interpretation or the experimentation of ideas, techniques and media. It ensures originality and creativity by new ways of presenting ideas and unusual use of media. The invention of new functions and ways of working

fields.name_eng: Interpretation
fields.description_eng: The understanding of experiences and events mainly through the reference frame of our own reality and contexts. The understanding of the meaning of an artist’s creative work and artistic expressions. An artist’s distinctive personal version expressed by stylistic individuality

fields.name_eng: Narrative
fields.description_eng: A spoken, written or visual account of connected events; a story, which may be fictional or non-fictional. The narrative may manipulate the viewpoint of the audience: bias is persuasive narrative designed to deliver a particular mandate, brief or point of view

fields.name_eng: Play
fields.description_eng: Play can occur in an artistic process or product. In process, play is experimentation — playing with ideas, characters, and techniques. This may be structured or free play. Improvisation is a structured approach to play, which often has the elements of a game and may involve particular rules. In product, play can be a collective creation of a theatre piece or a pre-existing piece of theatre that is authored and documented and that is transformed into live action

fields.name_eng: Presentation
fields.description_eng: The choice of medium, tool, and exhibition or performance space that contributes to audience understanding of the meaning or purpose of the art piece

fields.name_eng: Representation
fields.description_eng: The description, depiction or portrayal of a person, group, place or item in a particular way or as being of a certain nature. An image or likeness

fields.name_eng: Role
fields.description_eng: The development, adoption and portrayal of a character. The performer has to consider how to communicate the character’s psychology, emotions and physicality. This is concerned with examining situations, issues, concepts and texts from the perspective of a role. Different approaches, ideas and texts can be used to create and portray a character. The individual roles of instruments can be harmonic, rhythmic or melodic

fields.name_eng: Structure
fields.description_eng: This refers to the shape, timing and organization of the art and the factors that determine how a piece or performance is shaped. It takes into consideration form, function, narrative, melody, harmony, contrast, focus and the construction of smaller parts to create a whole

fields.name_eng: Style
fields.description_eng: A type of art characteristic of a group of people, person or period of time and belonging to a shared tradition or set of conventions. Art conforming to an established form

fields.name_eng: Visual culture
fields.description_eng: A field of study that generally includes some combination of cultural studies, art history, critical theory, philosophy, and anthropology, by focusing on aspects of culture that rely on visual images

fields.name_eng: Adaptation
fields.description_eng: Adaptation is the adjustment or changing of a skill, technique, strategy, tactic, process or choice in order to enhance its suitability to meet the needs of a situation or application. Adaptation may need to occur as a result of: environmental influences, feedback (internal and external), player interactions, team interactions and the outcomes of choices

fields.name_eng: Balance
fields.description_eng: Balance is a state of equilibrium between contrasting, opposing, or interacting factors. Balance can occur in many forms, such as the aesthetically pleasing integration of elements in movement routines, the team stability provided by the even distribution of player roles, as a means of judging and deciding upon lifestyle choices, or by placing equal importance on each dimension of health

fields.name_eng: Choice
fields.description_eng: Choice involves making a decision between at least two alternatives, knowing that, in making a choice, we will have to go without the other(s). Choices should be made by evaluating the situation and considering the resources available. Depending on the situation some choices will need to be decided upon quickly; such as choices required during game play. Other choices allow for longer periods of consideration; such as choices made in relation to nutrition or fitness development

fields.name_eng: Energy
fields.description_eng: Energy is a fundamental entity that is transferred between parts of a system in the production of change within the system. It is the capacity for doing work and as such the amount and form of energy an individual requires is dependent on the task(s) they are completing. The restoration of an individual’s energy levels is determined by a variety of factors such as rest, nutritional intake and time. Energy levels influence all aspects of human life, from our ability to think and make effective choices, to our ability to be physically active

fields.name_eng: Environment
fields.description_eng: Environment refers to the circumstances, objects, or conditions by which an individual is surrounded. The effective performance of techniques, skills, strategies and tactics are influenced by environmental factors. Performers must understand environmental influences in order to be successful. An environment does not have to be physical. The digital environment, especially social media, has a significant impact on personal, mental, emotional and social health

fields.name_eng: Function
fields.description_eng: A function is the action or role that something is specifically designed for or used to do. Functions can be voluntary or involuntary. A function can be part of a group of related actions that contribute to a larger action, such as the function of the heart contributing to the overall health of the human body, or the function of a setter in a volleyball team who is responsible for orchestrating their team’s offence. A variety of factors can influence the choice and effectiveness of specific functions

fields.name_eng: Interaction
fields.description_eng: An interaction is the result of two or more objects, groups or ideas affecting each other. Interactions can occur in a variety of forms, such as verbally, physically and digitally. Depending on their nature, successful interactions can contribute to improved personal, social and performance outcomes

fields.name_eng: Movement
fields.description_eng: Movement refers to the types and ways in which objects move. Sporting movements are normally divided into two categories: offensive (attacking) and defensive; however, various degrees occur within these two categories. Movement can also occur in relation to thoughts and ideas, a type of movement that relies on people aligning their thinking with others in relation to a specific cause or ideal

fields.name_eng: Perspective
fields.description_eng: Perspective enables the development of dif ferent interpretations, understandings and findings. Perspective can be gained through putting yourself in the place of others and striving to understand their opinions and disposition. People gain perspective by listening to others and considering the ways in which their points of view align or differ. Seeking and considering multiple perspectives is crucial to personal, mental and social health development, as well as to our ability to develop effective sporting techniques, tactics and strategies

fields.name_eng: Refinement
fields.description_eng: Refinement is the process of modifying something to enhance its overall  effectiveness. Refinement can occur in relation to personal behaviours, thought processes, techniques, tactics and strategies. Refinements are made based on internal and/or external feedback

fields.name_eng: Space
fields.description_eng: Space refers to the physical dimensions of a playing or performance area (for example, a badminton court), the distance between people or objects (for example offensive and defensive lines in field sports), and the opportunity to experience something (for example, space to discover identity). Space can be created, adapted, determined, used, taken, won and lost; therefore “space” is rarely absolute

fields.name_eng: Systems
fields.description_eng: Systems are sets of interacting or interdependent components that form an integrated whole. All individuals and communities rely on multiple systems working together to provide the structure and processes that they need in order to function effectively. Effective game play relies on participants’ understanding of multiple systems, including their components and interaction. Systems are often dynamic; they frequently need to be adapted to meet changing circumstances

fields.name_eng: Adaptation
fields.description_eng: Adaptation involves incorporating ideas found in one product into the development of a new product

fields.name_eng: Collaboration
fields.description_eng: Collaboration involves two or more people sharing expertise and experience, working together to solve a problem and realize shared goals

fields.name_eng: Ergonomics
fields.description_eng: Ergonomics is the application of scientific information and understanding of how humans relate to products, systems, interfaces and environments

fields.name_eng: Evaluation
fields.description_eng: In design, evaluation involves the gathering and processing of data to determine an action. Evaluation involves feedback, which can be used to control, revise or modify

fields.name_eng: Form
fields.description_eng: Form concerns the overall shape and configuration of a product. It relates to aspects such as aesthetics, shape, colour and texture

fields.name_eng: Function
fields.description_eng: The function of a solution refers to what it has been designed to do and how effective it is at enabling that action to be performed

fields.name_eng: Innovation
fields.description_eng: Innovation is the successful diffusion of an invention into the marketplace

fields.name_eng: Invention
fields.description_eng: An invention is an entirely novel product or a feature of a product that is unique

fields.name_eng: Markets and trends
fields.description_eng: Markets can be considered as sectors and segments comprised of groups of individuals with similar needs. Trends involve short- and long-term patterns of consumer behaviour

fields.name_eng: Perspective
fields.description_eng: Perspective relates to the point of view of various stakeholders involved in solving a problem. Stakeholders can have different perspectives and can include clients, target audiences, focus groups, consumers, manufacturers and experts.

fields.name_eng: Resources
fields.description_eng: Resources relate to the supply of a commodity. In MYP design, these commodities can be classified as information, materials and equipment

fields.name_eng: Sustainability
fields.description_eng:
Sustainability is the capacity to endure, which can have environmental, economic and social dimensions. In MYP design, sustainability can be considered in the following ways.
Green and Eco-design, Sustainable consumption, Sustainable design, Sustainable development, Sustainable innovation, Sustainable production

fields.name_eng: Identities and relationships
fields.description_eng: Students will explore identity; beliefs and values; personal, physical, mental, social and spiritual health; human relationships including families, friends, communities and cultures; what it means to be human.
fields.focus_questions_eng: Who am I? Who are we?

fields.name_eng: Orientation in space and time
fields.description_rus: Студенты будут изучать историю; дома и путешествия; переломные моменты человечества; открытия, исследования и миграции человечества; взаимоотношения между ними, и взаимосвязанности, людей и цивилизаций, в зависимости от личных, местных и глобальных точек зрения.
fields.focus_questions_eng: What is the meaning of “where” and “when”?

fields.name_eng: Personal and cultural expression
fields.description_eng: Students will explore the ways in which we discover and express ideas, feelings, nature, culture, beliefs and values; the ways in which we reflect on, extend and enjoy our creativity; our appreciation of the aesthetic.
fields.description_rus: Студенты будут изучать пути, по которым мы раскрываем и высказываем идеи, чувства, природы, культуры, верования и ценности; способы, с помощью которых мы оцениваем, развиваем и наслаждаемся творческим процессом, наше понимание эстетики.
fields.focus_questions_eng: What is the nature and purpose of creative expression?

fields.name_eng: Scientific and technical innovation
fields.description_eng:
Students will explore the natural world and its laws; the interaction between people and the natural world; how humans use their understanding of scientific principles; the impact of scientific and technological advances on communities and environments; the impact of environments on
human activity; how humans adapt environments to their needs.
fields.description_rus: Студенты будут изучать природный мир и его законы; взаимодействие между человеком и миром природы; то, как люди используют свое понимание научных принципов; влияние научно-технического прогресса на сообщества и защиту окружающей среды; влияние среды на деятельность человека; о том, как люди приспосабливаются в условиях для своих нужд.
fields.focus_questions_eng: How do we understand the world in which we live?
fields.focus_questions_rus: Как мы понимаем мир, в котором мы живем?

fields.name_eng: Globalization and sustainability
fields.description_eng: Students will explore the interconnectedness of human-made systems and communities; the relationship between local and global processes; how local experiences mediate the global; the opportunities and tensions provided by worldinterconnectedness; the impact of decision-making on humankind and the environment.

fields.name_eng: Fairness and development
fields.description_eng: Students will explore rights and responsibilities; the relationship between communities; sharing finite resources with other people and with other living things; access to equal opportunities; peace and conflict resolution.
fields.description_rus: Студенты будут изучать права и обязанности; отношения между общинами; совместное использование ограниченных ресурсов с другими людьми и другими живыми существами; «доступ к равным возможностям», мир и разрешение конфликтов
fields.focus_questions_eng: What are the consequences of our common humanity?

Inquirers
fields.description_eng: We nurture our curiosity, developing skills for inquiry and research. We know how to learn independently and with others. We learn with enthusiasm and sustain our love of learning throughout life.

fields.name_eng: Knowledgeable
fields.description_eng: We develop and use conceptual understanding, exploring knowledge across a range of disciplines. We engage with issues and ideas that have local and global significance.

fields.name_eng: Thinkers
fields.description_eng: We use critical and creative thinking skills to analyse and take responsible action on complex problems. We exercise initiative in making reasoned, ethical decisions.

fields.name_eng: Communicators
fields.description_eng: We express ourselves confidently and creatively in more than one language and in many ways. We collaborate effectively, listening carefully to the perspectives of other individuals and groups

fields.name_eng: Principled
fields.description_eng: We act with integrity and honesty, with a strong sense of fairness and justice, and with respect for the dignity and rights of people everywhere. We take responsibility for our actions and their consequences.

fields.name_eng: Open-Minded
fields.description_eng: We critically appreciate our own cultures and personal histories, as well as the values and traditions of others. We seek and evaluate a range of points of view, and we are willing to grow from the experience

fields.name_eng: Caring
fields.description_eng: We show empathy, compassion and respect. We have a commitment to service, and we act to make a positive difference in the lives of others and in the world around us.

fields.name_eng: Risk-Takers
fields.description_eng: We approach uncertainty with forethought and determination; we work independently and cooperatively to explore new ideas and innovative strategies. We are resourceful and resilient in the face of challenges and change.

fields.name_eng: Balanced
fields.description_eng: We understand the importance of balancing different aspects of our lives - intellectual, physical, and emotional - to achieve well-being for ourselves and others. We recognize our interdependence with other people and with the world in which we live.

fields.name_eng: Reflective
fields.description_eng: We thoughtfully consider the world and our own ideas and experience. We work to understand our strengths and weaknesses in order to support our learning and personal development.
